Name: fatty alcohol production, from palm oil | fatty alcohol | EN15804GD, U
Category: C:Manufacturing/20:Manufacture of chemicals and chemical products/201:Manufacture of basic chemicals, fertilizers and nitrogen compounds, plastics/2011:Manufacture of basic chemicals
Description: Average technology typical for European production conditions in the mid 90s. //Comment added during dataset update:// the petrochemical route has been designated as modern, since it has the good ability to change capacity with changes in demand compared to most oleochemical raw materials (with palm oil as an exception).;For the production out of palm oil, two main routes exist:;Fatty acid splitting and hydrogenation: The crude oil is contacted with high pressure/high temperature steam in the splitting step, resulting in the production of an aqueous phase containing glycerol and a gaseous phase containing crude fatty acids. In a second step, these fatty acids are transformed into fatty alcohols by the so-called “Lurgi direct hydrogenation”. ;Methyl ester production and hydrogenation:  in a first step, transesterification of crude or refined vegetable oils together with methanol is made and in a second step these methyl ethers are hydrogenated. It is possible to recover methanol an to return it to the first step - the transesterification.;Flow diagram of the different production ways for the production of fatty alcohols out of oleochemical raw materials :;Reference:;Noweck K. (2001) Fatty Alcohols. In: Ullmann's Encyclopedia of Industrial Chemistry, Sixth Edition, June 2001
